courseDescription: Development of the theory of supply and demand, and their interaction in a market economy.  Classical, Keynesian, and monetarist explanations of inflation and unemployment are presented and analyzed.  Emphasis is placed on income determination, fiscal policy, monetary policy, and the issue of government efforts to improve economic performance.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding fiscal and monetary policy tools
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting economic concepts to a non-specialist audience
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing economic data to make policy recommendations
Evaluating the impact of government interventions on the economy
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing strategies for economic policy implementation

courseDescription: An examination of how individuals and businesses interact in a market economy.  Emphasis is placed on consumer behavior, price and output decisions of firms, the economic efficiency of the resulting allocation of society's resources, and the gains from international trade and impact of trade barriers.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding market trends and data analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting complex economic concepts in a simple manner
Effective communication of market research findings to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing consumer behavior data to make informed decisions
Evaluating economic efficiency and resource allocation scenarios
Identifying gains from international trade and proposing strategies to mitigate trade barriers
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating with team members to analyze market data effectively

courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College.  A special honors section of ECON 201S.
Open only to students in the Honors College.  A special honors section of ECON 202S.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis with Excel or statistical software
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating on economic research projects with peers
Participating in economic debates or discussions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting economic data to make informed decisions
Analyzing economic policies and their impact on society
Creating economic models to predict outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group projects on economic topics
Managing time effectively for coursework and study

courseDescription: Examines the application of economic theory and methodology to managerial decision making and strategy.  Key topics are demand analysis, economic forecasting, production, cost analysis, the economics of organization, market structure and strategic behavior, pricing techniques, and government regulation and its implications for firm behavior.  Emphasis is placed on the global context of managerial decisions.

Develops methods of microeconomic analysis beyond the principles level.  Major emphasis is placed on consumer behavior and demand, production and cost, market organization, distribution theory, and welfare theory.

To make sense of the modern world and evaluate information through the lens of economics, it is imperative to be able to understand economic data, how it is used, how to use it, and what conclusions can be drawn from it. This course will explore the idea of causal inference (understanding if and how X causes Y to happen) and how economists and researchers evaluate potential causal relationships. Students will learn about how economists think about causality conceptually as well as econometric techniques using data with the R statistical programming language.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating potential causal relationships in economics

courseDescription: Supervised internship in economics.  Approval for enrollment and allowable credits is determined by the department CAP advisor and the Career Development Services in the semester prior to enrollment. Credit for internship and practicum in economics may not both be applied to meeting requirements for the major.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Professional communication with supervisors and colleagues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in an economics setting

courseDescription: Application of economic theory and principles to a practical problem of interest to a sponsoring community organization.  (Qualifies as a CAP experience.)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of economic analysis to non-experts
Presentation skills for conveying economic insights
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of economic theory to practical problems
Identifying solutions to economic challenges faced by community organizations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for economic research projects
Leading a team in economic analysis
Organizing and prioritizing economic research tasks

courseDescription: A study of selected topics, the title of which will appear in the course schedule.
A study of selected topics, the title of which will appear in the course schedule.
Technical and Digital Skills: Statistical analysis using software like R or Stata
Data visualization with tools like Tableau or Power BI
Financial modeling and analysis using Excel or Python
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting economic research findings to diverse audiences
Collaborating with team members on economic projects
Effective written communication for economic reports and proposals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Economic data interpretation and trend analysis
Identifying and resolving economic issues through quantitative analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading economic research teams on projects
Project management for economic data collection and analysis
Decision-making based on economic data and analysis

courseDescription: Provides students with a set of practical skills useful in economic research and in the presentation of research results.  Includes training in the use of various software packages, the Internet, and regression analysis for conducting economic research.

A survey of the transportation system in the United States including its development, pricing, and regulation.  Special attention is given to railroads, highways, pipeline, water and air transportation; and the roles that these modes of transportation play in economic development.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of railroads, highways, pipeline, water, and air transportation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of economic concepts in transportation
Collaboration with stakeholders in transportation projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing economic impact of different transportation modes
Developing solutions for economic development through transportation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating transportation initiatives for economic growth

courseDescription: Economic analysis of various facets of labor markets. Emphasis is placed on the analysis of labor supply, labor demand, wage determination, earnings differentials and inequality, occupational choice, human capital investment, labor market discrimination, mobility and immigration, impact of unions, and  unemployment.  This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Statistical analysis of labor market data
Economic modeling for labor supply and demand
Data visualization for wage determination analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective writing for economic analysis reports
Presenting labor market research findings to diverse audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying factors contributing to labor market inequality
Analyzing the impact of labor market discrimination on economic outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing research projects on labor market trends
Leading discussions on labor market policies and their implications

courseDescription: This course examines the interaction between government and the economy, with particular emphasis on the role of the federal government.  Topics that address the motivation for government involvement in the economy include market failure, income inequality, and redistribution of income.  Specific programs studied include Medicare/Medicaid, welfare programs, and the social security system.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting economic findings to non-specialist audiences
Team collaboration on policy research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating economic impact of government interventions
Forecasting budget implications of policy changes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research teams on economic policy studies
Managing timelines and resources for policy analysis projects

courseDescription: The course focus is on the use of differential and integral calculus, matrix algebra, difference equations and classical optimization theory in the presentation and development of economic theory.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in economic theory analysis

courseDescription: A study of market structures and the conduct and performance of business firms in different market structures.  The emphasis is on the theory and measurement of industrial concentration and public policy responses to industrial concentration.

This course introduces the student to the economics of health care and the application of health economics to health care problems, the issues surrounding those problems, and the potential solutions to those problems.  The course will emphasize institutional features of the health care industry, the market for health care, the political economy of health care, and government involvement in the delivery of health care.  Further, the course will survey the delivery of health care in other countries and provide a global perspective on selected health care issues such as AIDS, water and air quality, and the aging of the population.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing economic models for health care issues
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting economic findings in health care
Collaborating with experts in health economics
Effective communication of health care policy recommendations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying solutions for health care problems
Critical evaluation of global health care issues

courseDescription: This course introduces the student to the economics of sports in America.  The course will emphasize institutional features of the sport industry.  Specific topics included are: sports franchises as profit-maximizing firms; monopoly and antitrust rules as applied to the sports industry; public finance of sports; costs and benefits of a sports franchise to a city: the labor economics of professional sports; discrimination in sports; and the economics of college sports.  This course may not be applied toward the major in economics as an economics elective or toward the minor in economics or the M.A. in economics.  (It could, however, be used as a non-economics elective for the major.)
Technical and Digital Skills: Monopoly and antitrust rules application in sports
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting economic insights in sports industry
Collaborative research on sports economics topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of economic data in sports industry
Identifying costs and benefits in sports franchise analysis
Analyzing discrimination in sports from an economic perspective
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on sports economics topics
Organizing research projects on sports economics

courseDescription: An analysis of the economic factors which give rise to the formation of urban centers and which contribute to the following problems: urban poverty, housing conditions, traffic congestion, and the fiscal crisis faced by modern cities.  This is a writing intensive course.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in urban economics research
Team collaboration on urban economic projects

courseDescription: Topics discussed include conservation and scarcity, market failure, fishery management, benefit-cost analysis, water resource development, environmental quality, recreation, energy, and marine resources.  This is a writing intensive course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective writing skills for environmental economics
Collaborating with stakeholders in environmental decision-making
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for environmental economics research
Organizing and facilitating group projects in the field of natural resources

courseDescription: An analysis of the principles of trade theory and policy with an overall exposition of the principles of international finance.  The main objective of the course is to provide knowledge of analytical tools used by economists in analyzing contemporary international economic problems.

A study of the history of economic theory with attention to the economic ideas and philosophy of Adam Smith, David Ricardo, Karl Marx, J.M. Keynes and other major figures in the development of economics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis using historical economic data
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting historical economic ideas and theories
Engaging in academic debates on economic philosophy
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of economic theories on historical events
Evaluating the evolution of economic thought over time
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing research projects on key economic thinkers

courseDescription: This course is intended to provide an introduction to the problems of economic development in the Third World, including the problems of economic growth, income distribution, poverty, urbanization, uneven development, agricultural policy, economic planning, industrial policy, trade policy, balance of payments, finance, and currency crises.  To illustrate these issues we will examine the problems of certain individual countries, such as Brazil, Korea, Philippines, India, Mexico, Kenya, Indonesia, and Thailand.  The course tries to strike a balance between economic theory and institutional economics.  This is a writing intensive course.

This course examines and compares different economies from around the world, including such economies as the UK, France, Germany, Sweden, Japan, India, Korea, Russia, and China.  Students look at the economic growth, GDP per capita, unemployment, inflation, income distribution, economic efficiency, institutions, policies, industrial structure, legal infrastructure, and international trade of these economies.  Students study the functioning of markets and the problems of market and government failure.  The course addresses the question, what is the best way to organize society.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding economic indicators like GDP, unemployment, and inflation
Analyzing economic data using statistical software
Comparing international trade data between economies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting economic analysis findings to a diverse audience
Collaborating with peers on comparative research projects
Debating the merits of different economic systems with classmates
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying market failures and proposing solutions
Analyzing the impact of government interventions on economic efficiency
Evaluating the effectiveness of legal infrastructure on market operations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on economic system comparisons
Organizing research materials from multiple economies
Delegating tasks effectively in group projects

courseDescription: Taught on an occasional basis.  A study of selected topics, the title of which will appear in the course schedule.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in economic analysis, data interpretation and forecasting, qualitative and quantitative research methods
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Research project management, team collaboration in data collection and analysis

courseDescription: Designed to provide the advanced student in economics an opportunity to do independent study under the guidance of a member of the faculty.

A survey of the transportation system in the United States including its development, pricing, and regulation.  Special attention is given to railroads, highways, pipeline, water and air transportation; and the roles that these modes of transportation play in economic development.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding transportation systems in the US
Knowledge of railroads, highways, pipelines, water, and air transportation systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of transportation economic concepts
Collaboration with stakeholders in transportation sector
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing economic impact of different transportation modes
Developing strategies for improving transportation efficiency

courseDescription: Economic analysis of various facets of labor markets. Emphasis is placed on the analysis of labor supply, labor demand, wage determination, earnings differentials and inequality, occupational choice, human capital investment, labor market discrimination, mobility and immigration, impact of unions, and  unemployment.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating on labor market research projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing labor market data for analysis

courseDescription: This course examines the interaction between government and the economy, with particular emphasis on the role of the federal government.  Topics that address the motivation for government involvement in the economy include market failure, income inequality, and redistribution of income.  Specific programs studied include Medicare/Medicaid, welfare programs, and the social security system.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of government programs impact on economy
Data analysis for economic policy evaluation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting economic findings to diverse audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying market failures in the economy
Developing redistribution strategies based on economic indicators

courseDescription: A study of market structures and the conduct and performance of business firms in different market structures.  The emphasis is on the theory and measurement of industrial concentration and public policy responses to industrial concentration.

Examines the nature and functions of money and credit, the commercial banking system, the Federal Reserve System, the quantity theory of money, the theory of income determination, the balance of payments and exchange rates, and the history of monetary policy in the United States.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of the Federal Reserve System
Knowledge of balance of payments and exchange rates
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of trends in banking systems

courseDescription: This course introduces the student to the economics of health care and the application of health economics to health care problems, the issues surrounding those problems, and the potential solutions to those problems.  The course will emphasize institutional features of the health care industry, the market for health care, the political economy of health care, and government involvement in the delivery of health care.  Further, the course will survey the delivery of health care in other countries and provide a global perspective on selected health care issues such as AIDS, water and air quality, and the aging of the population.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing economic models in health care analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with international health care professionals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying inefficiencies in health care systems
Developing solutions for health care challenges
Utilizing economic tools for health care decision-making
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading global health care research projects

courseDescription: An analysis of the economic factors which give rise to the formation of urban centers and which contribute to the following problems: urban poverty, housing conditions, traffic congestion, and the fiscal crisis faced by modern cities.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting economic findings to diverse audiences
Collaborating with urban planners and policymakers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying root causes of urban poverty
Developing solutions for housing issues in urban areas
Analyzing traffic patterns for congestion reduction

courseDescription: Topics discussed include conservation and scarcity, market failure, fishery management, benefit-cost analysis, water resource development, environmental quality, recreation, energy, and marine resources.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with stakeholders on resource management plans
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating interdisciplinary teams for environmental impact studies

courseDescription: A study of the history of economic theory with attention to the economic ideas and philosophy of Adam Smith, David Ricardo, Karl Marx, J.M. Keynes and other major figures in the development of economics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research skills in economic literature analysis
Data analysis with economic data sets
Digital research methods for historical economic texts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting complex economic theories in a clear and engaging manner
Collaborating with peers on historical economic research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and comparing economic theories from different historical periods
Identifying key economic ideas and philosophies in historical texts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on historical economic theories
Organizing research materials for historical economic analysis

courseDescription: This course is intended to provide an introduction to the problems of economic development in the Third World, including the problems of economic growth, income distribution, poverty, urbanization, uneven development, agricultural policy, economic planning, industrial policy, trade policy, balance of payments, finance, and currency crises.  To illustrate these issues we will examine the problems of certain individual countries, such as Brazil, Korea, Philippines, India, Mexico, Kenya, Indonesia, and Thailand.  In the course we try to strike a balance between economic theory and institutional economics.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying root causes of economic challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in economic development initiatives
Conflict resolution in economic policy debates

courseDescription: This course examines and compares different economies from around the world, including such economies as the UK, France, Germany, Sweden, Japan, India, Korea, Russia, and China.  Students look at the economic growth, GDP per capita, unemployment, inflation, income distribution, economic efficiency, institutions, policies, industrial structure, legal infrastructure, and international trade of these economies.  Students study the functioning of markets and the problems of market and government failure.  The course addresses the question, what is the best way to organize society?
Taught on an occasional basis.  A study of selected topics, the title of which will appear in the course schedule.

This course introduces the MBA student to the use of economic analysis to aid managerial decision-making.  Topics include demand and supply, theory of optimizing behavior, demand elasticity, production, cost analysis and pricing with and without market power.  Other topics include an introduction to game theory, alternative pricing techniques and the internal organization of firms.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination for effective managerial outcomes

courseDescription: This course examines the measurement of macroeconomic variables and their movements over time.  Short-run and long-run models of the macroeconomy are covered along with institutional factors of financial markets.  The course mixes theory with real world applicability.  Students will examine critical economic policy issues of the day.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of economic data and analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of macroeconomic variables and trends
Development of short-run and long-run macroeconomic models
Identification of institutional factors impacting financial markets

courseDescription: This course focuses on the use of mathematical techniques in solving complex economic problems.  Primary emphasis is given to matrix algebra, differential calculus, constrained optimization techniques and dynamic optimization techniques.

An analysis of international trade theory, commercial policy, foreign exchange markets, open economy macroeconomics, and balance of payments.  The course provides the theoretical basis to understand contemporary international economic issues. (Credit may not be applied toward the M.A. in economics.)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Forecasting economic trends in international markets
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on global economic issues
Organizing research on contemporary international economic topics

courseDescription: The course is a practicum in the field of economics applying theories, concepts, and quantitative tools in a professional environment.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with team members on projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying economic theories to real-world scenarios

courseDescription: Advanced topics in economics specifically designed for school teachers.  (Credit may not be applied toward the M.A. in economics or the MBA.)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear communication of complex economic theories
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Mentoring and guiding students in economic research projects

courseDescription: Advanced topics in economics are covered in this course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis using R or Stata

courseDescription: Individual readings in a selected field under the direction of a faculty member of the department.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying economic concepts to real-world scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively for independent research
Taking initiative in selecting and analyzing readings
Leading group discussions on economic topics

courseDescription: Students writing the capstone empirical research paper will take this course. Under the supervision of a faculty member, students will discuss theoretical models, analytical techniques, data analysis, and policy recommendations resulting from their capstone research project.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying theoretical models to real-world data

courseDescription: Directed research for thesis.

This course provides the skills necessary to successfully identify, acquire, manage, and analyze economic data. The course primarily focuses on the application of statistical methods in support of economic analysis. During the course, students will (1) develop research hypotheses; (2) identify data to test the hypotheses; (3) utilize coding to access and obtain data, (4) use descriptive statistics to discuss the properties of the data, (5) explore the bivariate least squares estimator, and (6) interpret and present the results of economic analysis.
Technical and Digital Skills: Coding for data access and manipulation

courseDescription: This course considers microeconomic theory as a means of organizing the behavior of individuals and firms in economic settings. The course provides the theoretical framework for microeconomic research in business and in government. The theory of the household and the theory of the firm will be presented in detail along with consideration of distribution theory and welfare theory. The material will be presented with the aid of graphical techniques, logic, calculus, matrix algebra, and optimization techniques.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of microeconomic research findings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of graphical techniques in economic analysis

courseDescription: This course presents classical and modern macroeconomic models, including the Solow growth model, the Ramsey infinite horizon model, the overlapping generations model, and the endogenous growth model. The course also explores classical and modern models of monetary policy. This course provides students with mathematical and analytical tools and techniques to analyze macroeconomic issues including the impact of monetary and fiscal policy and the interaction among inflation, unemployment, and interest rates.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of monetary and fiscal policy impacts
Interpretation of inflation, unemployment, and interest rate interactions

courseDescription: Single-equation econometric models; serial correlation, heteroscedasticity, specification error, missing observations, and errors-in-variables and forecasting.

Multi-equation econometric models; problems such as identification, single-equation estimation, estimation of equation systems, and model evaluation techniques; time-series models such as autoregressive and moving average models; forecasting with time-series models.

Issues in cross-section and panel data, focuses on problems such as selection bias, heterogeneity, unobserved heterogeneity, treatment effects, truncation and censoring.  The course covers multivariate techniques such as principal component analysis and factor analysis, along with event studies and nonparametric and semiparametric estimators.

Pure theory of international trade, mathematical models of trade, instruments of trade policy, theory and practice of economic integration, trade liberalization issues from international and regional viewpoints.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to analyze economic integration theory
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of international trade theories
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills in managing trade projects

courseDescription: Introduction to the problems of economic development in the third world, including the problems of economic growth, income distribution, poverty, urbanization, uneven development, agricultural policy, economic planning, industrial policy, trade policy, balance of payments, finance, and currency crises.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying root causes of economic problems
Developing solutions for income distribution issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Guiding finance and currency crisis response efforts

courseDescription: Designed to provide the advanced student with an opportunity to study independently or in small groups and investigate specific topics of current interest in the field of economics.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of economic trends and patterns

courseDescription: This course considers microeconomic theory as a means of organizing the behavior of individuals and firms in economic settings. The course provides the theoretical framework for microeconomic research in business and in government. The theory of the household and the theory of the firm will be presented in detail along with consideration of distribution theory and welfare theory. The material will be presented with the aid of graphical techniques, logic, calculus, matrix algebra, and optimization techniques.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Graphical techniques interpretation for economic models

The course also explores classical and modern models of monetary policy. This course provides students with mathematical and analytical tools and techniques to analyze macroeconomic issues including the impact of monetary and fiscal policy and the interaction among inflation, unemployment, and interest rates.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Impact assessment of monetary and fiscal policy

courseDescription: Single-equation econometric models; serial correlation, heteroscedasticity, specification error, missing observations, and errors-in-variables and forecasting.

Multi-equation econometric models; problems such as identification, single-equation estimation, estimation of equation systems, and model evaluation techniques; time-series models such as autoregressive and moving average models; forecasting with time-series models.

Issues in cross-section and panel data, focuses on problems such as selection bias, heterogeneity, unobserved heterogeneity, treatment effects, truncation and censoring.  The course covers multivariate techniques such as principal component analysis and factor analysis, along with event studies and nonparametric and semiparametric estimators.
Technical and Digital Skills: Multivariate techniques (e.g., principal component analysis, factor analysis)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and mitigation of selection bias
Handling truncation and censoring in datasets

courseDescription: Pure theory of international trade, mathematical models of trade, instruments of trade policy, theory and practice of economic integration, trade liberalization issues from international and regional viewpoints.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of international trade theories

courseDescription: Introduction to the problems of economic development in the third world, including the problems of economic growth, income distribution, poverty, urbanization, uneven development, agricultural policy, economic planning, industrial policy, trade policy, balance of payments, finance, and currency crises.
Designed to provide the advanced student with an opportunity to study independently or in small groups and investigate specific topics of current interest in the field of economics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data visualization with R or Python
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and coordinating group discussions on economic topics

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Professional communication with faculty and peers

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
